docs.lead_paragraph: After the football team added its clout to protests over racial issues, Timothy Wolfe announced that he was stepping down as president of the four-campus system, and the chancellor, R. Bowen Loftin, said he would move into another job.

headline.main: University of Missouri Protests Spur a Day of Change
headline.print_headline: Campus Protests at Missouri Spur a Day of Change

docs.abstract: University of Missouri president Timothy M Wolfe resigns and chancellor R Bowen Loftin will step down in wake of months of student and faculty protests over racial tensions and other issues; threat of boycott by Missouri football team added clout to charges of racism.
docs.snippet: After the football team added its clout to protests over racial issues, Timothy Wolfe announced that he was stepping down as president of the four-campus system, and the chancellor, R. Bowen Loftin, said he would move into another job.

byline.contributor: John Eligon reported from Columbia, and Richard Pérez-Peña from New York. Reporting was contributed by Marc Tracy and Austin Huguelet from Columbia; Monica Davey and Mitch Smith from Chicago; and Alan Blinder from New York.
byline.original: By JOHN ELIGON and RICHARD PÉREZ-PEÑA

docs.lead_paragraph: President Barack Obama is already citing the decision not to proceed with the Keystone XL pipeline as one of the key accomplishments of his presidency.

headline.main: Obama Points to Blocking Keystone as Top Accomplishment
headline.print_headline: Obama Points to Blocking Keystone as Top Accomplishment

docs.snippet: President Barack Obama is already citing the decision not to proceed with the Keystone XL pipeline as one of the key accomplishments of his presidency.

headline.main: Your Monday Briefing: Myanmar Elections, University of Missouri, James Bond

docs.snippet: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.

docs.lead_paragraph: Searching for economic and cultural reasons why middle-aged white Americans are dying sooner.
docs.abstract: Paul Krugman Op-Ed column ponders several explanations for findings of recent Angus Deaton and Anne Case study showing spike in mortality rate of middle-aged white Americans since 1990.
docs.snippet: Searching for economic and cultural reasons why middle-aged white Americans are dying sooner.

docs.lead_paragraph: Commissioners are recommending sweeping new standards to address complaints from consumers about limited access to doctors and hospitals in health plans sold under the Affordable Care Act.
docs.abstract: Insurance regulators propose broadening doctor and hospital networks to ensure consumers with Affordable Care Act health plans receive affordable, easy access to appropriate care; insurers claim smaller networks meet consumers' demand for low prices, while many patients are angry their usual providers are no longer covered.
docs.snippet: Commissioners are recommending sweeping new standards to address complaints from consumers about limited access to doctors and hospitals in health plans sold under the Affordable Care Act.

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: Without the right policies to keep the poor safe from extreme weather and rising seas, climate change could drive over 100 million more people into poverty by 2030, the World Bank said on Sunday.

headline.main: World Bank Warns Climate Change Could Add 100 Million Poor by 2030
headline.print_headline: World Bank Warns Climate Change Could Add 100 Million Poor by 2030

docs.snippet: Without the right policies to keep the poor safe from extreme weather and rising seas, climate change could drive over 100 million more people into poverty by 2030, the World Bank said on Sunday.

docs.lead_paragraph: A new report from the World Bank finds that the poorest people are more exposed to climate-related shocks such as floods, droughts and heat waves than those with average incomes.

headline.main: Factbox: How Does Climate Change Make People Poorer?
headline.print_headline: Factbox: How Does Climate Change Make People Poorer?

docs.snippet: A new report from the World Bank finds that the poorest people are more exposed to climate-related shocks such as floods, droughts and heat waves than those with average incomes.

docs.lead_paragraph: We need to evaluate whether new drugs are really worthwhile, because the costs are widely, although perhaps invisibly, shared.

headline.main: I Am Paying for Your Expensive Medicine
headline.print_headline: I Am Paying for Your Expensive Medicine

docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by Dr Ezekiel J Emanuel contends debate over price of pharmaceuticals should focus on both question of medical value delivered by any given drug, and whether that value can be linked to its price; holds Americans resistant to government regulation may have far fewer objections if they realize just how high insurance premiums can go if drug manufacturers are allowed to continue to set astronomical prices for new classes of drugs.
docs.snippet: We need to evaluate whether new drugs are really worthwhile, because the costs are widely, although perhaps invisibly, shared.

docs.lead_paragraph: The health law has been a success in several respects but is also a reminder that reducing inequality is a formidable challenge.

headline.main: Obamacare Not as Egalitarian as It Appears

docs.abstract: The Upshot; Tyler Cowen Economic View column observes that Affordable Care Act has cost possibly 20 percent less than anticipated and has reduced amount of Americans without insurance; notes however that by some measures law has had only limited impact on economic inequality.
docs.snippet: The health law has been a success in several respects but is also a reminder that reducing inequality is a formidable challenge.
